utterances: I think sometimes people who are exercise fanatics or who do a lot of running, they become, quote-unquote, the runner.
That's their identity, and it's very difficult if somebody has to give that up.
They can't imagine any other satisfying way to stay fit.
Pereles says he empathizes, especially now as he, himself, a long-distance runner, is nursing a serious ankle injury.
As we talk, he has one leg elevated and a walker on wheels.
It's not what he expected at 47.
It's very hard.
And people say, well, what are you going to do?
What are you going to do?
And you really have to adapt.
You have to look at the long range, and it's a matter of transition.
Which can be tough, because with the transition comes the acceptance that you may have to alter your expectations and acknowledge your limits.
Myself, I just had this operation about a month ago, and so it is difficult.
And you really do have to force yourself into a routine.
And that takes will power.
Pereles says his new routine, once he recovers, will likely include more swimming and biking, which aren't hard on the joints.
He says with his patients, a big part of getting them over the hump is to help them design new exercise routines.
In fact, I will sit with people, and I will make it part of the visit to establish a habit.
When can we squeeze it in?
Those who are successful in establishing new habits, Pereles says, tend to view their workouts as appointments that can't be broken, something that most runners already have a leg up on.
Over the decades, Howard Stoodley says he's always tried to keep his appointments.
As I've gotten older, I tend to wake up real early.
I woke up at 3:30 this morning, but the first thing I did was about 40 minutes of exercise.
So I do that every day.
I don't miss a day.
His routine is definitely not as rigorous as it once was, and Stoodley says sometimes in his sleep, he still dreams that he's running.
You've got to play the cards you're dealt.
So if you can't run, then you walk.
I walk almost every day.
Right.
Amazon didn't start out as a computer company, unlike, say, Apple.
For Amazon, the computer is simply a means to an end.
Amazon was a store that just happened to be online, and you can get at it on whatever device you wanted.
Primarily a bookstore - at first.
And though Amazon sells much more than books now, you can buy basically anything you would ever want on Amazon, it's their identity as a bookseller that drove them to make tablets.
I think it was driven by a realization that more and more reading was going to happen on these objects, rather than on books.
And if it was going to stay in the book business, it had to move into this new platform.
You've heard the expression, there's no such thing as a free lunch?
The practice by bars in the mid-19th century in the United States, to give you a free meal if you had drinks.
And, of course, there was lots of salt in the meal.
The Kindle Fire's not free, but it's certainly cheap.
And if having one of those makes you thirsty for more Amazon products, then the loss pays off.
Zoe Chace, NPR News, New York.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
The list of great theatrical sports is a pretty short one.
There's roller derby, there's wrestling, and, well, that's about it.
So Jayme Dyer didn't know what to expect two years ago when she signed up for a women's arm wrestling event in Durham, North Carolina.
But for her, it had all the right ingredients: it empowered women, it was bawdy, it was fun, and it raised money for causes like domestic violence shelters.
So this past summer, she found herself representing Durham at the very first National Championships of CLAW, the Collective of Lady Arm Wrestlers.
Producer Brad Horn followed Dyer through multiple costume changes as she set out to bring home the championship cape.
The first time I competed in arm wrestling, I had no idea what I was doing, and I'd never arm wrestled anybody before.
And I won.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #1: All performers are allowed two alcoholic drinks during the event.
I won the first round.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: Wrestlers may not induce any messy substance...
I won the second round.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: Performers may not reveal genitalia.
And I almost won the championship round.
And I was like, holy cow, if this is how well I can do when I haven't even been training, then man, I got to start lifting weights.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
CLAW is a Collective of Lady Arm Wrestlers, which is the overarching umbrella of many smaller leagues throughout the country.
SuperCLAW is the first arm wrestling event with one representative from each league coming together and arm wrestling each other.

I grew up in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
Single mom, single daughter.
It was the two of us kind of against the world.
And she has bipolar disorder, and we didn't know that until after I left.
But when I was 16, she attempted suicide, and I saw it.
And the police took me out of her home.
I felt like Pig-Pen.
I was walking around with this cloud of dirt.
And I remember walking to work and thinking everybody who's driving by could see this stain on my soul.
They all know that I'm this horrible person.
And I had to survive either by shutting down or by looking at it.
And I looked at it.
So where's that outfit from?
(as Ze Dirty Butcher) That is a good question.
